Yes, Eliza Gardner was the daughter of Marie Therese Raison de La Geneste Gardner and Joseph Gardner. She was born on June 1, 1831, in Barboursville, Cabell County, Virginia (now West Virginia), and was raised in a family of successful businesspeople.

Eliza Gardner went on to become an accomplished educator and writer. In 1850, she attended Miss Sarah P. Vose's Young Ladies' School in Boston, Massachusetts, and later taught at a school in Baltimore, Maryland. She also contributed articles and poetry to various newspapers and magazines, including the Anglo-African Magazine and the New York Tribune.

In addition to her literary pursuits, Eliza Gardner was involved in various social and political causes. She was a supporter of abolitionism and women's suffrage, and was involved in efforts to establish schools for African American children in the South. She was also a member of the Women's Loyal National League, which worked to secure passage of the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which abolished slavery.

Eliza Gardner never married and passed away on January 15, 1890, in Washington, D.C. She was buried in the family plot at Spring Hill Cemetery in Huntington, West Virginia.
Was Eliza Gardner Joseph Miller's mom?
No, Eliza Gardner was not Joseph Miller's mother. Joseph Miller was the husband of Marie Therese Raison de la Geneste Gardner, Eliza Gardner's daughter.

I apologize for the mistake earlier. Joseph Miller, the son of William Mueller and Eliza Gardner, was a lawyer who practiced in Huntington, West Virginia. He served as the Prosecuting Attorney for Cabell County from 1877 to 1880 and was appointed United States Attorney for the Southern District of West Virginia by President Grover Cleveland in 1893. He also served as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1908. He died in Huntington on February 22, 1921.

Eliza Gardner was the daughter of Marie Therese Raison de la Geneste and Joseph Gardner. She was born around 1820, likely in Virginia or West Virginia. Eliza was of mixed-race descent, with African and European ancestry. Her mother Marie Therese was also of mixed-race, and her father Joseph Gardner was a white man.

Not much is known about Eliza's life, but it is known that she married William Mueller, a German immigrant, in 1843. They had at least one child together, a son named Joseph Mueller (later known as Joseph Miller), who would become a lawyer and work for the IRS during the presidency of Grover Cleveland. Eliza and William later divorced, and Eliza remarried to a man named Samuel Gardner.

Eliza's life and the lives of her family members reflect the complexities of race and identity in the United States during the 19th century, particularly for those of mixed-race heritage.
